bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, February 25, 1943

div1.p: Hench is anxious to see Truby's book. Hench then mentions that he read Finlay's book, which supports the Cuban perspective that the Americans only confirmed, not proved, the mosquito theory.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, February 25, 1943
div1.opener:
STATION HOSPITAL
Camp Carson, Colorado
February 25, 1943
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
It must be a real thrill to see your book in proof, and I
am very anxious indeed to see it. I think the suggestion that you
use Cornwell's picture is excellent, and I know that Mr. Kellogg
will be delighted to let you have the colored prints. As a matter
of fact, I believe he will not only let you have the prints, but will
probably have them printed for inserts. Months ago when he was ask-
ing me how my own book was coming, he very eagerly offered me the
colored prints, but of course mine will not appear for a fairly long
time. I suggest that you write him at once, or better yet, wire him,
requesting either the prints or the actual inserts. I know that all
they will want will be the printed line - Courtesy of John Wyeth and
Brothers. There is absolutely no reason why you shouldn't use it.
Their other pictures, especially the one on Beaumont, have been used
in many high grade publications. You have, therefore, an excellent
precedent for using the yellow fever painting - it will add much to
your book and, with you actually in the painting, it will be of re-
ciprocal value, giving your friends pleasure, and also lending more
authenticity to your book (if any more authenticity is needed). So
far the yellow fever painting has been reproduced not too many times.
As you know, I used it in the Hygea article. A picture becomes
famous not just because it is a good picture, but because it becomes
a familiar oft-reproduction. I think Cornwell's picture deserves to
become familiar to every one. Kelly might want to use the reproduc-
tion as a frontespiece rather than having the reproduction back in
the appropriate chapter. That is for you to decide. I am delighted
that you will be allowed to have so many pictures in your book.

Finley's book is very nice, and of course stresses the
Cuban view point that the American physician merely confirmed what
Finley had already proved. Finley himself pointed out one or two min-
or errors in it, but these are a small matter.

General Kean is still fine. I had a very nice long letter
from him just a few days ago. He is still reminiscing most happily
on the receipt of the Gorgas Medal, and is apparently still getting
letters of congratulation from friends from whom he has not heard
for years. It was all a very happy event.

You will be surprised to know that our young buck pri-
vate decided to arrive in Colorado rather than in Rochester. Mary
came out to visit me about two and a half weeks ago, and had made
reservations to leave this last Sunday evening, as it was not to be
until March 13. Just 24 hours before she had planned to leave the
youngster decided to do something about it, with the result that he
was born Sunday evening, February 21, one minute before midnight,
on my father's birthday - a very happy coincident, as he was named
after my father. Mary is doing splendidly and the little fellow is
very cute indeed. We are very, very happy as we have long wanted
two of each and now have two boys and two girls. One of my associa-
tes raised the question, “Is this merely a seventh inning stretch
for Colonel Hench or the end of the ball game?” - only time will
tell.
div1.closer:
Always sincerely, P. S. HENCH Lieut Colonel, M. C.
PSH:RA
